newsitem.title: UK: Zinc sparkles, boosts others in LME pre-market.
newsitem.headline: Zinc sparkles, boosts others in LME pre-market.

text.p: Zinc prices exploded to 4-1/2 year highs on Thursday morning in a fund-related move which helped the other LME metals snap to attention.
Extending late Wednesday's gains, three-month zinc prices burst above the psychological $1,300 level and the early April high of $1,311 to trade as high as $1,323, the highest since October 1992.
Zinc was last indicated at $1,322/24, compared to Wednesday's kerb close of $1,287.
Traders attributed the move to a new bout of fund buying which started on Wednesday and subsequently encountered little resistance on Thursday morning.
"It broke back up yesterday and then fuelled itself higher above $1,300, hitting stops all the way up to $1,323 today," a trader said.
"This morning fresh fund buying is not finding any producer selling as most of Europe is shut for Ascension Day," said another.
Fund and speculative buying have propelled zinc close to $300 higher so far this year.
On the way up, prices were expected to encounter resistance around $1,325, the high from October 1992, and at then $1,350.
The other metals were generally firmer across the board, spurred in part by zinc's rally.
Copper was up $10 at $2,380, around the top end of the recent range. Further on, $2,400 would provide stiff resistance, traders said.
Cash/threes widened out by around $5 to $67/$70.
Aluminium also built on Wednesday's gains, reaching a fresh six-week high of $1,672, up $11. Next resistance was expected in the $1,680-$1,685 area.
Analysts said borrowing of nearby spreads was helping boost three month prices. Cash/threes narrowed to a $21/$23 contango, compared to near $30 mid-afternoon on Wednesday.
Lead, initially marked up with zinc, was also displaying an upward bias and was last trading $10 firmer at $635.
"It hesitated at first but now lead is finding some interest," a trader said.
